instance.본문: No doubt students collaborating with other speakers of English might encounter language variances, which may interfere with intentionality. (1)To address such disparities, Horner, Lu, Royster, and Trimbur (2011) call for a “translingual approach” in which language varieties are not perceived as barriers, but as avenues for meaning making. (2) S i m i larly, Galloway and Rose (2015) study of Global Englishes found that exposure to other Englishes helps normalize language differences. (3)Educators have to work with students to examine phrases, expressions, and other ranges of English language use for their rhetorical and communicative possibilities and not their perceived errors or inferior status. (4)Committing an error means unintentionally saying what isn’t true, so any linguistic or perspective error should be avoided at all cost. (5)After all, students are constantly reading texts and listening to speakers whose Englishes do not necessarily conform to what is considered standard in their own communities.
instance.해설:

(4) 오류를 범하는 것은 의도치 않게 진실이 아닌 것을 말하는 것을 의미하므로, 어떤 언어적 또는 인식적 오류도 반드시 피해야 한다. (5) 결국, 학생들은 자신의 공동체에서 표준으로 간주되지 않는 영어를 사용하는 텍스트를 읽고 있는 사람들이나 연설을 듣는 것에 지속적으로 노출되고 있다." 

"해설": "이 글은 학생들이 다양한 영어 변종을 접하는 것이 왜 중요한지에 대해 논의하고 있다. 첫 문장은 학생들이 언어적 차이를 경험할 것이라는 내용을 담고 있다. (1)번 문장은 Horner 외의 연구자들이 제안한 '초언어적 접근법'을 설명하고 있다. (5)번 문장은 학생들이 표준 영어가 아닌 다양한 영어에 지속적으로 노출된다는 내용을 포함한다. 그러나 (4)번 문장은 오류를 피해야 한다는 내용으로서, 앞뒤 문장과 논리적 혹은 주제적으로 연결되지 않으며 글의 주제에서 벗어난 내용이다."}

instance.질문: 다음 글에서 전체 흐름과 관계 없는 문장은?
instance.본문: Doctors Without Borders, also known as Médecins Sans Frontières or MSF, was founded in 1971 by a small group of French doctors. They believed that all people have the right to medical care regardless of race, religion, gender, and political belief. (1)It was the first non-governmental organization to provide emergency medical assistance. (2)A private, nonprofit organization, MSF is at the forefront of emergency health care as well as care for populations suffering from endemic diseases. (3)It provides primary health care, performs surgery, runs nutrition programs, trains local medical personnel, and provides mental health care. (4)Health care, a primary concern of many people, is limited to developed countries. (5)Through longer-term programs, this organization treats chronic diseases such as malaria, sleeping sickness, and AIDS; and brings health care to remote, isolated areas where resources and training are limited.

instance.질문: 다음 글에서 전체 흐름과 관계 없는 문장은?
instance.본문: Have you ever done something absent­minded like throwing the peeled potato into the bin and the peelings into the pot? (1)How about sending an email saying there is a document attached without actually attaching the document? (2)Everyday mistakes like these happen all the time because our brains have to keep track of hundreds of different responses to thousands of different potential stimuli every hour of our waking lives. (3)Even though a second earlier we wrote that we were attaching a document to the email, the very next second our brain gives a command to our fingers to send the attachment­less email. (4)It is wise not to open email attachments from an unknown, doubtful, or untrustworthy source. (5)Sometimes we don’t even realize our mistake until we get an email from the addressee pointing it out.
instance.해설: {"해석": "당신은 깎은 감자를 쓰레기통에 버리고 껍질을 냄비에 넣는 것 같은 아무 생각 없는 행동을 한 적이 있나요? (1) 첨부 파일이 있다고 말하면서 실제로는 첨부 파일을 붙이지 않고 이메일을 보낸 적은요? (2) 이런 일상적인 실수는 우리의 두뇌가 우리의 깨어 있는 매 시간 동안 수천 가지의 잠재적인 자극에 대한 수백 가지의 다른 반응을 추적해야 하기 때문에 항상 발생합니다. (3) 1초 전에 이메일에 문서를 첨부한다고 썼음에도 불구하고, 그 다음 순간 우리의 뇌는 첨부 파일 없는 이메일을 보내라는 명령을 손가락에 내립니다. (4) 알 수 없거나 의심스럽거나 신뢰할 수 없는 출처에서 온 이메일 첨부 파일을 열지 않는 것이 현명합니다. (5) 때때로 우리는 수신인으로부터 그것을 지적하는 이메일을 받을 때까지 우리의 실수를 깨닫지 못합니다.", "해설": "제시된 글의 첫 부분과 마지막 부분을 먼저 읽어보면, 일상적인 실수와 관련한 내용임을 알 수 있습니다. 글의 각 문장은 이런 실수가 왜 발생하는지, 그리고 우리의 두뇌가 어떻게 작동하는지를 설명하고 있습니다. 따라서 매끄러운 논리적 전개가 나타납니다. 그러나 (4)번 문장은 알 수 없거나 의심스러운 출처의 이메일 첨부 파일을 열지 말라고 조언하는 내용으로, 일상적인 실수나 두뇌의 작동 방식과는 관련이 없습니다. 이 때문에 (4)번 문장은 글의 흐름과 관계 없는 문장으로 판단됩니다."}

instance.본문: As far back as the seventeenth century, hair had a special spiritual significance in Africa. Many African cultures saw the head as the center of control, communication, and identity in the body. (1)Hair was regarded as a source of power that personified the individual and could be used for spiritual purposes or even to cast a spell. (2)Since it rests on the highest point on the body, hair itself was a means to communicate with divine spirits and it was treated in ways that were thought to bring good luck or protect against evil. (3)People had the opportunity to socialize while styling each other’s hair, and the shared tradition of hair was passed down. (4)According to authors Ayana Byrd and Lori Tharps, “communication from the gods and spirits was thought to pass through the hair to get to the soul.” (5)In Cameroon, for example, medicine men attached hair to containers that held their healing potions in order to protect the potions and enhance their effectiveness.

instance.본문: We are the only species that seasons its food, deliberately altering it with the highly flavored plant parts we call herbs and spices. It’s quite possible that our taste for spices has an evolutionary root. (1)Many spices have antibacterial properties—in fact, common seasonings such as garlic, onion, and oregano inhibit the growth of almost every bacterium tested. (2)And the cultures that make the heaviest use of spices—think of the garlic and black pepper of Thai food, the ginger and coriander of India, the chili peppers of Mexico—come from warmer climates, where bacterial spoilage is a bigger issue. (3)The changing climate can have a significant impact on the production and availability of spices, influencing their growth patterns and ultimately affecting global spice markets. (4)In contrast, the most lightly spiced cuisines—those of Scandinavia and northern Europe—are from cooler climates. (5)Our uniquely human attention to flavor, in this case the flavor of spices, turns out to have arisen as a matter of life and death.
instance.해설:
